columns.text: In this exercise, we are to determine the amounts required in the balance sheet using the percentage of sales approach.

## Percentage of Sales Approach
\
The percentage of sales approach is a financial planning model in which the concept is to separate the accounts in the income statement and in the balance sheet into two sections- one which is directly affected by sales and the other which does not.
\
Through the sales forecast, the amount of the necessary funding is determined that will support the estimated sales of the company.

The information in the previous exercise is as follows:
 

<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Income Statement||
|$\hspace{20pt}$Sales|\$49,000|
|$\hspace{20pt}$Cost|\$40,300|
|$\hspace{30pt}$Taxable Income|\$8,700|

|$\hspace{20pt}$Net Income|\$6,786|
|Dividends|\$2,400|

Now, let us prepare the balance sheet using the following given:

|$\hspace{20pt}$Retained Earnings|\$3,950|
The problem will require us to compute the proportionate share of the balance sheet accounts to the sales.

### Let's first provide the given data in the problem.

* Accounts payable vary with sales.
* Notes payable do not vary with sales.
* Declared dividends is $2,400.00.
* Addition to retained earnings $4,386.00.

### Last, provide the given balance sheet.

## Requirement 

### Compute the proportionate share of the balance sheet accounts to the sales.

The assets are proportionate to the projected increase in sales, while the accounts payable and the equity section are not automatically proportional to the increase in sales unless otherwise stated in the problem.

### Compute the proportional share of cash to the sales.

The proportional share of an asset account should be maintained when there are projected sales.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Share of Cash in the Sales}&= \dfrac{\text{Cash}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]


\end{aligned}
$$

### Compute the proportional share of accounts receivable to the sales.

The proportional share of an asset account should be maintained when there are projected sales.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Share of  Accounts Receivable in the Sales}&= \dfrac{\text{Accounts Receivable}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]


\end{aligned}
$$

### Compute the proportional share of inventory to the sales.

The proportional share of an asset account should be maintained when there are projected sales.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Share of Inventory in the Sales}&= \dfrac{\text{Inventory}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]


\end{aligned}
$$

### Compute the proportional share of net plant equipment to the sales.

The proportional share of an asset account should be maintained when there are projected sales.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Share of Net Plan Equip't in the Sales}&= \dfrac{\text{Net Plant Equipment}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]


\end{aligned}
$$

### Compute the proportional share of accounts payable to the sales.

Based on the problem, accounts payable vary with sales. Therefore, the proportional share of accounts payable to the sales should be computed.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Share of Accounts Payable in the Sales}&= \dfrac{\text{Accounts Payable}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]


\end{aligned}
$$

The following accounts are not proportional to the sales.

* Accounts Payable
* Long Term Debt
* Retained Earnings 
* Common stock and Additional Paid in Capital

These accounts are not automatically proportional to sales unless otherwise it is clearly stated by the company.
